steps.title: Thread one side of the lace through the bottom eyelet.
steps.content: Thread one side of the lace through the bottom eyelet. The eyelets are the small holes on the front of the boot. You can thread the lace through the eyelet from the outside or push the laces in through the holes from the middle of the shoe. Try both methods to see which style you prefer. [1] X Research source Threading the laces from the outside lends itself well to the loose and criss-cross styles.

steps.title: Thread the other side of the lace into the opposite eyelet.
steps.content: Thread the other side of the lace into the opposite eyelet. If you laced from the outside in, the laces will wrap around the bottom eyelets. If you are lacing from the inside out, the laces will wrap over the leather to the next eyelet up. Lace both ends of the shoelace in the same way. For example, if the left side is going from the outside into the center of the shoe, the right side of the lace should do the same thing.

steps.title: Match the lace length by pulling both ends of the lace.
steps.content: Match the lace length by pulling both ends of the lace. Pull the ends of the shoelace up so that each side of the shoelace is the same length. This will ensure that your shoelaces aren’t lopsided when you reach the top holes. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Choose a lacing style and lace the rest of your shoes.
steps.content: Choose a lacing style and lace the rest of your shoes. Now that you've started off your laces, you can choose a style and lace the rest of your shoes. If you need to wear your Timberlands for physical labor, make sure to use the criss-cross or army style to keep your boots tight on your feet. If you're wearing Timberlands for fashion, choose the loose style.

steps.title: Cross the left lace over and thread it through the opposite hole.
steps.content: Cross the left lace over and thread it through the opposite hole. Cross the left lace over and thread it through the next highest hole on the right side of the boot. Take the right lace and do the same thing. Pull on both ends of the lace to tighten them. You should see an X. Criss-cross lacing is good if you need your shoes to stay securely on your feet.

steps.title: Repeat the process until you’ve laced your laces through every eyelet.
steps.content: Repeat the process until you’ve laced your laces through every eyelet. Continue crisscrossing your laces all the way up your shoe until you don’t have any more empty eyelets. After making every cross, remember to pull on both ends of the shoelace to tighten your boot.

steps.title: Skip the highest holes if you don’t have any more lace.
steps.content: Skip the highest holes if you don’t have any more lace. You'll need at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) on each end of the lace in order to tie a knot. If you run out of shoelace, avoid threading the laces through the very top eyelets in your shoes. Not threading the top holes will leave you enough lace so that you can properly tie a knot. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Tie your shoes
steps.content: Tie your shoes . Tie a bow with your laces as you normally would to tie your shoes. You can put the bow in front or behind the tongue of the Timberland, depending on whether you want your laces to show. If you're working in your boots, tuck the laces behind the tongue so that they don't come undone and so that you don't trip over them. [4] X Research source Pull on both ends of the laces to tighten your Timberlands before you tie your knot or bow.

steps.title: Thread the laces through the eyelets immediately above the laces.
steps.content: Thread the laces through the eyelets immediately above the laces. Instead of crisscrossing over to the other side, as you would in a traditional or criss-cross lacing, take the end of the left lace and push it through the hole or eyelet directly above the one that it’s currently in. Repeat the process on both ends of the lace. You should now see your shoelace run vertically through the holes. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Cross the laces and thread them through the next highest hole.
steps.content: Cross the laces and thread them through the next highest hole. Cross the laces over the center of the shoe and push them through the holes on the opposite side of your shoe. Crisscrossing is necessary to keep the laces tight. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Thread the laces through the holes above them.
steps.content: Thread the laces through the holes above them. Repeat what you did earlier and don’t cross the laces. Run them vertically to the next highest eyelet. Your shoelaces should now look like they run vertically on the bottom, cross over, then run vertically again on the third eyelets from the bottom. [7] X Research source Your laces should then criss-cross through the next holes.

steps.title: Repeat the pattern until your boots are fully laced.
steps.content: Repeat the pattern until your boots are fully laced. Alternate between crisscrossing and vertical lacing all the way up the shoe. Because you’re using vertical lacing, you should have more shoelace towards the top which will make tying a knot easier.

steps.title: Tie a knot or bow at the top.
steps.content: Tie a knot or bow at the top. Once your boots are tight, tie them as you normally would. Your laces should now look unique while remaining functional.

steps.title: Use the criss-cross or straight style but skip the fourth hole.
steps.content: Use the criss-cross or straight style but skip the fourth hole. Lace your shoes up to the fourth eyelet from the bottom, using either a criss-cross or a straight pattern. Instead of lacing the shoelace through the fourth hole, however, skip the hole and go to the next highest hole, or the fifth eyelet. [8] X Research source This style is fashionable but isn't great if you're doing manual labor. Skipping holes will give your Timberlands a looser, more casual look.

steps.title: Thread the laces through the fifth hole.
steps.content: Thread the laces through the fifth hole. Insert the lace into the fifth hole and pull it. While this may look strange on other shoes, it often doesn’t look weird with Timberlands. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Tie a knot at the top.
steps.content: Tie a knot at the top. If you feel like you have too much extra shoelace, you can thread the laces through the sixth, or top hole. Otherwise, tie a knot as you usually would and put it in front or behind the boot’s tongue.

steps.title: Create individual knots on both sides of the lace.
steps.content: Create individual knots on both sides of the lace. If you want to try for a different look, you can tie a traditional overhand knot on both ends of the shoelace instead of tying them together with a bow or a knot. This will prevent the laces from coming loose while you walk around and is a unique and stylish way to tie your shoes. [10] X Research source
